column1: Jahazpur is a city and a municipality in Bhilwara district in the Indian state of Rajasthan. It is particularly known for its Jain temple and is built around a fort.

Jahazpur is located at 25.62°N 75.28°E﻿ / 25.62; 75.28. It has an average elevation of 334 metres (1095 feet). There is a Jain Mandir in the shape of a Jahaz (ship) being built there popularized as Atishay Kshetra dedicated to Bhagwan Munisuvrata Nath.The under construction temple is on the Jahazpur-Shahpura (Bhilwara) State Highway No. 39 around 24 km from Deoli a town in Tonk District of Rajasthan on the National Highway running from Jabalpur to Jaipur.

column3: 816. Males constitute 51% of the population and females 49%. Jahazpur has an average literacy rate of 59%
column4: lower than the national average of 59.5%: male literacy is 72%
column5: and female literacy is 45%. In Jahazpur
column6: 16% of the population is under 6 years of age.

column1: Jahazpur along with Hasteda is known for its ancient idols of Lord Munisuwartnath. The temple at Jahazpur and hasteda is dedicated to Munisuvrata the twentieth Tirthankara of Jainism. The Moolnayak idol at Jahazpur temple is a black-coloured idol of Bhagwan Munisuvrata Swami. This idol is considered miraculous.
The statue of Bhagwan Munisuvrat Nath was unearthed from the ground dug for the construction of a house in Jahazpur in 2013.
There is a historical temple of Lord Shiva in the village of Luhari-Kalan and is famous among the locals.
Jahazpur State was founded in 1572 by Jagmal Singh Sisodiya brother of Maharana Pratap when he was denied the Kingship so he went to Mughal Service and Akbar gifted him Jahazpur Jagir
column2: he used Rao as his title; Jahazpur State existed until 1758
column3: when Maratha forces invaded the Jahazpur fort and then the rulers shifted to Anjar.
